pull.title: build: osx: Fix incomplete framework packaging for codesigning
pull.body:
Starting with 10.9, Framework versions must be signed individually, rather
than as a single bundle version, in order to be properly codesigned. This
change ensures that the proper plist files and symlinks are present prior to
packaging.

I believe I've tested this on all of my build scenarios, including the future static qt.

@gavinandresen Please give this a real-world try (preferably by merging it into -rc1 locally and signing a gitian build there as though it were rc2) before ACKing. It worksforme (tm), but that means very little for Apple's tools.

Also, note that --deep will be needed for codesign until we switch to static libs.

events.message:
build: osx: Fix incomplete framework packaging for codesigning

Starting with 10.9, Framework versions must be signed individually, rather
than as a single bundle version, in order to be properly codesigned. This
change ensures that the proper plist files and symlinks are present prior to
packaging.

events.body:
Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4758_65f3fa8d11a9b2e139d4963514fdc1beb04dfb68/ for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.

Perhaps also worth noting that to pass codesigning checks on Yosemite you will need to codesign the releases with a machine running nothing older than 10.9 as well. Any signatures by machines older than 10.9 are being invalidated by 10.10 automatically.

Relevant sections:

"Signatures created with OS X v10.8.5 or earlier ("v1 signatures") are
obsoleted and will no longer be recognized by Gatekeeper. To ensure
your apps will run on updated versions of OS X they must be signed
using the codesign tool on OS X v10.9 or later ("v2 signatures")."

"App extensions for OS X are always run as 64-bit code.  You will need
to build your extensions, and any shared frameworks they depend upon,
to include 64-bit support"
Yea, that's the ultimate purpose of this change. Signing now works properly on 10.9, so we can keep Gatekeeper happy in the future.
@wumpus : this should be cherry-picked if there is another 0.9.3 release candidate.
